title: Explore fixing coverage reports after screenshots that are automatically committed back
description:

title: Post Build Process - Service Worker Pre-cache for App Shell
description:
Serving local static resources cache-first means that one can get all the crucial scaffolding for our SkyUX2 web app - The App Shell—on the screen without having to wait for any network responses.

### Expected behavior
1. Enable everyone to participate in the ecosystem of good!
2. Enable instant loading of our app shells: on, offline, or in high latency environments. 
3. Reduce network, cpu, I/O, memory usage of servers and increase load times

### Actual behavior
Online - App downloads from servers.
Offline - App does not load.
Latency - App takes a long time to load or will timeout.

### Steps to reproduce
Emulate a network disconnection or latency in chrome tools. 

### Resources
Service Worker Precache 
https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-precache#wrappers-and-starter-kits
Webpack Plugin for sw-precache
https://www.npmjs.com/package/sw-precache-webpack-plugin

title: Allow SPAs to extend Builder's webpack configs

### Expected behavior
A SPA can extend the `build`, `serve`, and `test` webpack configurations. The specific use case would more than likely involve custom loaders or plugins.

```
{
  "mode": "easy",
  "compileMode": "aot",
  "webpackConfigs": {
    "build": ["./config/build.webpack.config.js"],
    "serve": ["./config/serve.webpack.config.js"],
    "test": ["./config/test.webpack.config.js"]
  }
}
```

title: Combine skyux2 and skyux-builder repos.
description:
After further discussion and watching how user's consume us, we think combining the skyux2 component library and the skyux-builder code might be more efficient and beneficial.

The skyux-cli would remain separate.  It's installed globally which means consumer are less likely to update it (even with the auto prompts to upgrade we implemented).  Keeping that in mind means we want to keep it as lightweight as possible and contain as little logic as possible.

It performs two basic functions:

- Globally register `skyux` as a known command.
- Handle the commands that can be run outside the context of a project: `skyux help` and `skyux new`

Perhaps as a first past, we could leave the repos/packages separate, but at least have builder require skyux2 (or vice-versa) and remove that requirement in the current skyux-template.

Possible complications to the "quick" approach we discussed today.  Even if we took the first approach of removing skyux-builder from the template, and moved it as a dependency for skyux, we'd have to update CLI to either not look in package.json or look for skyux instead.

title: Run skyux visual tests through a skyux page
description:
Currently we are running our visual regression tests by using webpack to serve some component fixtures up locally, and then use the local Browserstack tunnel to test using multiple browsers. 

This has a couple of drawbacks:

  - The Browserstack local tunnel can be flakey and disconnect randomly at times
  - Serving up our files with webpack doesn't allow us to have as many tests running in parallel, because they start slowing down to the point of failure as we add more.
  - Our visual tests are not being run in a environment similar to our users (SKY UX host/builder/etc)
 
To solve this, we should find a way to build our visual tests as a SKY UX app, which our visual tests will then hit remotely.

title: Lightboxing/dimming behind modals can be bypassed by scrolling/resizing
description:
### Expected behavior
When a modal is open, the background page is dimmed so that only the controls on the modal are clickable. The dimmed area should cover the entire page, regardless of window size and scrolling

### Actual behavior
If the page has a scrollbar, you can scroll past the dimmed area and click on navigation elements, links, etc. Also, the dimmed out area scales with the resizing of the browser window. So if you reduce the height of the browser window, you can create more clickable space that isn't dimmed

### Steps to reproduce

Precondition: Have a sky page that contains enough content to need scrollbars and has an action that launches a modal.

1. Navigate to the sky page that meets the precondition and launch the modal.
2. Scroll downward on the page. You'll see that the dimmed area does not extend to the bottom of the page. ![dimming01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21042636/21504697/17c0bef8-cc16-11e6-8fc6-6cbf43525b77.png)
3. Resize the window. You'll see that the dimmed area resizes with the window. Creating a even larger space not covered by the dimming. If you shrink the browser window enough, you can have full access to any part of the page while the modal is still open. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21042636/21504738/47159fd4-cc16-11e6-825d-55a4703c9c7f.png)

description:
When viewing the HTML report generated by Istanbul during unit test runs, the code coverage displayed is for the transpiled JS code rather than the original TS code.  In CodeCov the TS code is displayed but the highlighted lines match up with the transpiled JS code.  We need to figure out a way to use something like [remap-instanbul](https://github.com/SitePen/remap-istanbul) to map coverage back to the original TS file.

There's a [thread on the angular2-webpack-starter repo](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/178) on which the SKY UX 2 project is based that describes difficulties integrating remap-istanbul with their project.
